DOCNAME: CASE OF ANHEUSER-BUSCH INC. v. PORTUGAL
JUDGES: András Baka;Antonella Mularoni;Christos Rozakis;Corneliu Bîrsan;Elisabeth Steiner;Giovanni Bonello;Ireneu Cabral Barreto;Jean-Paul Costa;Josep Casadevall;Karel Jungwiert;Khanlar Hajiyev;Lech Garlicki;Loukis Loucaides;Lucius Caflisch;Luzius Wildhaber;Nicolas Bratza;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Stanislav Pavlovschi;Volodymyr Butkevych
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant is an NORP public company whose registered office is in GPE , GPE ) . It produces and sells beer under the brand name “ Budweiser ” in a number of countries around the world .

CARDINAL . The applicant company has sold beer in GPE under the “ Budweiser ” mark since DATE . It broke into the NORP markets in DATE and says that it began to sell “ Budweiser ” beer in GPE in DATE .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant company ’s decision to extend the sale of its beers to LOC led to a dispute with a NORP – now NORP DATE company called ORG . ORG produces a beer in the town of ORG in GPE ( GPE ) which is also called “ Budweiser ” . The term comes from PERSON , the NORP name for the town . The applicant company alleges that ORG has only been marketing beer under the “ Budweiser ” name since DATE , whereas PERSON says that it has been entitled to use that appellation since DATE , when ORG of ORG conferred the right to produce the beer on a number of independent brewers in České GPE ( PERSON in NORP ) . The brewers used a special technique and beers produced by this method became known by the term “ Budweiser ” , just as beers produced using the methods of another NORP town , PERSON ( NORP in NORP ) , became known as “ NORP ” .

CARDINAL . According to the information before the ORG , the applicant company concluded CARDINAL agreements in DATE with PERSON concerning the distribution and sale of “ Budweiser ” beer in GPE . However , these agreements did not deal with the question of the right to use the “ Budweiser ” name in LOC . As a result , the CARDINAL companies became embroiled in a series of legal proceedings over the right to use the term “ Budweiser ” in various NORP countries , including GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant company applied to ORG ( PERSON ) to register “ Budweiser ” as a trade mark on the industrial - property register . The PERSON did not grant the application immediately because it was opposed by PERSON , which alleged that “ Budweiser Bier ” had been registered in its name as an appellation of origin since DATE . PERSON had effected the registration under the terms of FAC of DATE for ORG and their International Registration ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . The applicant company then applied to ORG on DATE for an order cancelling PERSON registration . A summons was served on PERSON , but it did not file a defence . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( which , in the absence of an appeal , became final ) , ORG granted the applicant company ’s application on the ground that the product to which the registration referred , namely the beer known as “ Budweiser Bier ” , was not an appellation of origin or indication of source . ORG Instance noted that under the terms of LAW of DATE such protection was reserved to the geographical name of a country , region , or locality , which served to designate a product originating therein , the quality and characteristics of which were due exclusively or essentially to the geographical environment , including natural and human factors . “ Budweiser ” did not come within this category . The registration was therefore cancelled .

CARDINAL . Following the cancellation of the appellation of origin , and despite the fact that ORG had challenged the application for registration under the opposition procedure , the ORG registered the “ Budweiser ” trade mark in the applicant company ’s name on DATE in a decision that was published on CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON appealed to ORG against the PERSON ’s decision on the strength of an agreement between the governments of GPE and the Czechoslovak Socialist Republic on ORG , Appellations of Origin and Other Geographical and Similar Designations ( “ LAW ” ) , which was signed in GPE on DATE and which came into force on DATE , after publication in ORG . As required by law , the applicant company was invited by the court to take part in the proceedings as an interested party . In DATE it was served with the originating summons that had been lodged by PERSON .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , ORG Instance dismissed the appeal . It found that the only intellectual property eligible for protection under NORP law and LAW ( which , according to the court was no longer in force , owing to the disappearance of CARDINAL of the contracting parties , GPE ) was the “ PERSON ” appellation of origin , not the “ Budweiser ” trade mark . In addition , it found that there was no risk of confusion between the appellation of origin and the applicant company ’s trade mark , which the vast majority of consumers tended to think of as an NORP beer .

CARDINAL . Budějovický Budvar appealed against that decision to ORG , alleging , inter alia , a breach of LAW , sub - paragraphs ( l ) and ( j ) , of LAW . In a judgment of DATE , ORG overturned the impugned judgment and ordered the PERSON to refuse to register “ Budweiser ” as a trade mark . ORG did not consider that there had been a breach of LAW , as the expression “ Budweiser ” was incapable of misleading the NORP public as to the origin of the beer concerned . However , it found that such a registration would infringe LAW and , consequently , LAW j ) of LAW . In that connection , it noted that LAW had remained in force , following an exchange of notes between the NORP and NORP governments ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and had been incorporated into domestic law by virtue of LAW , which contained a clause providing for international law to take effect in the NORP legal system .

CARDINAL . The applicant company appealed on points of law to ORG alleging , inter alia , that the impugned decision contravened LAW of DATE on ORG ( “ the TRIPs Agreement ” ) , which establishes the rule that registration confers priority , and in particular its LAW and CARDINAL § DATE . The applicant company also alleged that , in any event , the protected appellation of origin “ PERSON ” did not correspond to the NORP expression “ Budweiser ” , so that LAW could not be used to challenge its application for registration . The applicant company argued that , even supposing that the NORP expression “ Budweiser ” was an accurate translation of the NORP appellation of origin , LAW applied only to translations between NORP and NORP , not to translations into other languages . It submitted , lastly , that LAW was unconstitutional owing to a formal defect in that it had been adopted by the government , not ORG , in breach of ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the LAW governing parliamentary sovereignty .
CARDINAL . ORG dismissed the appeal on points of law in a judgment of DATE , which came to the applicant company ’s attention on DATE .

With regard to ORG , ORG began by noting that the provision on which the applicant company relied required it to have acted in good faith before going on to say that the applicant company had not referred in its application for registration to any factual information that demonstrated its good faith . In any event , the effect of DATE of ORG was that it had not become binding under NORP law until DATE , that is to say after the entry into force of the DATE LAW . ORG therefore found that ORG could not take precedence over LAW .

As regards the interpretation of LAW , ORG considered that the intention of the CARDINAL contracting GPE in entering into it had incontestably been to protect through reciprocal arrangements their respective national products , including when translations of a name were used . The appellation of origin “ PERSON ” , which became “ PERSON ” or “ NORP ” in NORP , indicated a product from the České GPE region in GPE . It was therefore protected by LAW .
Lastly , the procedure whereby the ORG had been adopted did not contravene Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the LAW , since it did not concern a sphere for which ORG had exclusive competence .

CARDINAL . The Agreement between the governments of GPE and the Czechoslovak Socialist Republic on ORG , Appellations of Origin and Other Geographical and Similar Designations was signed in GPE in DATE and came into force on DATE . In a note verbale dated DATE , the NORP Minister for ORG indicated that GPE would succeed GPE as a contracting party to the Agreement . The NORP Minister for ORG agreed thereto on behalf of GPE in a note verbale dated DATE .
CARDINAL . DATE Agreement provides , inter alia :

“ CARDINAL . If a name or designation protected under this Agreement is used in commercial or industrial activities in breach of the provisions of this Agreement for products ... all judicial or administrative remedies available under the legislation of ORG in which protection is sought to prevent unfair competition or the use of unlawful designations shall , by virtue of the LAW , be deployed to restrain such use .
CARDINAL . NORP The provisions of this Article shall apply even when translations of the said names or designations are used ... ”
Appendix A to the Agreement lists the designations “ ORG pivo ” and “ PERSON ” among the protected appellations of origin .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant company , GPE entered into similar agreements with CARDINAL other member ORG , these being GPE and GPE . The agreement between GPE and GPE was signed on DATE and came into force on DATE . The agreement between GPE and GPE was signed on DATE and came into force on CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . The Paris Convention of DATE for ORG , as subsequently revised on numerous occasions ( the most recent being in GPE on DATE , United Nations Treaty Series DATE , vol . CARDINAL , pp . CARDINAL et seq . ) , sets up a Union for the protection of industrial property , an expression that encompasses industrial designs , trade marks , appellations of origin and indications of source . The purpose of ORG is to prevent discrimination against non - nationals and it lays down a number of rules of a very general nature dealing with the procedural and substantive aspects of industrial property law . It enables owners of marks to obtain protection in various member ORG through a single registration . It also establishes the priority rule , which grants , for a set period , a right of priority to an application for protection of an intellectual property right in one of GPE over applications lodged subsequently in another Contracting State . The system introduced by this convention is administered by ORG ( WIPO ) based in GPE ( GPE ) .
CARDINAL . The following provisions of LAW are of relevance to the present case :

“ A. ( CARDINAL ) Any person who has duly filed an application for ... the registration of ... an industrial design , or of a trademark , in CARDINAL of the countries of the Union , or his successor in title , shall enjoy , for the purpose of filing in the other countries , a right of priority during the periods hereinafter fixed .

( CARDINAL ) Any filing that is equivalent to a regular national filing under the domestic legislation of any country of the ORG or under bilateral or multilateral treaties concluded between countries of the ORG shall be recognized as giving rise to the right of priority .

( CARDINAL ) By a regular national filing is meant any filing that is adequate to establish the date on which the application was filed in the country concerned , whatever may be the subsequent fate of the application .

B. Consequently , any subsequent filing in any of the other countries of the ORG before the expiration of the periods referred to above shall not be invalidated by reason of any acts accomplished in the interval , in particular , another filing , ... the use of the mark , and such acts can not give rise to any third - party right or any right of personal possession . Rights acquired by third parties before DATE first application that serves as the basis for the right of priority are reserved in accordance with the domestic legislation of each country of the Union
C. ( CARDINAL ) The periods of priority referred to above shall be ... DATE for industrial designs and trademarks .

“ ( CARDINAL ) The countries of the ORG undertake , ex officio if their legislation so permits , or at the request of an interested party , to refuse or to cancel the registration , and to prohibit the use , of a trademark which constitutes a reproduction , an imitation , or a translation , liable to create confusion , of a mark considered by the competent authority of the country of registration or use to be well known in that country as being already the mark of a person entitled to the benefits of this LAW and used for identical or similar goods . These provisions shall also apply when the essential part of the mark constitutes a reproduction of any such well - known mark or an imitation liable to create confusion therewith .
CARDINAL . GPE , GPE ( succeeded by GPE ) and GPE were all Contracting Parties to LAW at the material time .

CARDINAL . LAW Concerning LAW and LAW of DATE establish and govern a system for the international registration of marks that is administered by ORG . ORG was revised in GPE ( DATE ) , GPE ( DATE ) , GPE ( DATE ) , GPE ( DATE ) , GPE ( DATE ) and GPE ( DATE ) . The DATE LAW established the “ GPE ” composed of GPE Parties to ORG and the Contracting Parties to the LAW . GPE became a party to the Agreement on DATE . GPE has not ratified the Agreement . It ratified LAW on DATE .

CARDINAL . The system set up by ORG is applicable to the members of ORG and affords owners of a mark a means of securing protection in various countries through a single application for registration in a national or regional registry . Under the system , the registration of an international mark has the same effect in the countries concerned as an application to register the mark or registration of the mark by the owner directly in each individual country . If the trade - mark registry of a member ORG does not refuse protection within a fixed period , the mark enjoys the same protection as if it had been registered directly by that registry .

CARDINAL . LAW for ORG and their International Registration was signed in GPE on DATE , revised in GPE on DATE and amended on DATE . It enables ORG to request other ORG to protect appellations of origin of certain products , if they are recognised and protected as such in the country of origin and registered at ORG . Both GPE and GPE , as a successor to GPE , are parties to this Agreement .

CARDINAL . The Agreement on Trade - Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights was concluded in the Uruguay Round of the negotiations that resulted in the signature in DATE of ORG ( ORG ) Agreements in GPE , which came into effect on DATE . The aim of this Agreement is to integrate the system of intellectual - property protection into the system of world - trade regulation administered by the ORG . The member States of the ORG undertake to comply with the substantive provisions of LAW .
CARDINAL . The provisions of ORG of relevance to the present case are as follows :

“ CARDINAL . In respect of Parts II [ Standards Concerning the Availability , Scope and Use of Intellectual Property Rights ] , III [ Enforcement of LAW ] and ORG and ORG ] of this Agreement , Members shall comply with ORG CARDINAL through CARDINAL , and LAW , of LAW ( DATE ) .

“ CARDINAL . The owner of a registered trademark shall have the exclusive right to prevent all third parties not having the owner ’s consent from using in the course of trade identical or similar signs for goods or services which are identical or similar to those in respect of which the trademark is registered where such use would result in a likelihood of confusion . In case of the use of an identical sign for identical goods or services , a likelihood of confusion shall be presumed . The rights described above shall not prejudice any existing prior rights , nor shall they affect the possibility of Members making rights available on the basis of use .

“ Members may provide limited exceptions to the rights conferred by a trademark , such as fair use of descriptive terms , provided that such exceptions take account of the legitimate interests of the owner of the trademark and of third parties . ”
“ Where a trademark has been applied for or registered in good faith , or where rights to a trademark have been acquired through use in good faith either :
( a ) before the date of application of these provisions in that Member as defined in Part VI ; or
( b ) before the geographical indication is protected in its country of origin ;

measures adopted to implement this Section shall not prejudice eligibility for or the validity of the registration of a trademark ... on the basis that such a trademark is identical with , or similar to , a geographical indication . ”

“ Subject to the provisions of paragraphs CARDINAL , CARDINAL and DATE [ which provide for longer periods ] , no Member shall be obliged to apply the provisions of this Agreement before the expiry of a general period of DATE following the date of entry into force of ORG . ”

CARDINAL . European Union law contains various instruments designed to regulate and protect intellectual property , including trade marks . The instrument of most relevance to the present case is ORG ( ORG ) No . CARDINAL of DATE on the ORG trade mark , which establishes a right to a ORG trade mark and confers certain rights on applicants for registration . Its aim is to promote the development , expansion and proper functioning of the internal market by enabling ORG undertakings to identify their products or services in a uniform manner throughout the ORG . To that end , ORG for the Internal Market ( OHIM ) has been established ( for trade marks and designs – LAW . It is based in GPE ( GPE ) . Applications for registration of a Community trade mark are sent to the LAW , which decides whether to grant or reject them . An appeal lies against its decisions to the ORG ’s ORG , and from there to ORG of ORG ( Articles DATE ) .

CARDINAL . DATE , which is entitled “ The application for a Community trade mark as an object of property ” , lays down that the provisions relating to Community trade marks also apply to applications for registration . These provisions include LAW ) , LAW in rem ) , LAW of execution ) and LAW ) . By virtue of LAW , an application for registration may also found a claim for compensation .

CARDINAL . Finally , LAW of the draft LAW establishing a LAW for LOC , signed on DATE , but not yet in force ) , which guarantees the right to property , provides : “ Intellectual property shall be protected . ”

CARDINAL . In accordance with the relevant international instruments , the legislation of most of the member ORG regards registration as a corollary to the acquisition of the right to the mark . However , the vast majority of the States also regard the application for registration of the mark as conferring certain rights . In most cases , once registered the mark is deemed to have been valid since the date the application for registration was filed ( system of retrospective protection through registration ) . The date of filing also determines priority in the system of international marks . Lastly , in some countries , an application to register a mark may itself be the subject of provisional registration , while in others it may be the subject of an assignment , security assignment or licence and ( provided the mark is subsequently registered ) create an entitlement to compensation in the event of fraudulent use by CARDINAL party .

CARDINAL . NORP In most countries , registration is preceded by publication of notice of the application and a procedure whereby interested parties can oppose registration in adversarial proceedings . However , in some countries , registration is automatic if the competent authority is satisfied that the application satisfies the formal and substantive requirements . In both cases , in accordance with the applicable international rules , an action to have a mark revoked or declared invalid may be brought within a set period . Such actions may be based on grounds such as valid prior title , prior application , right to international priority or a failure to use the mark for a certain period .

CARDINAL . The substantive and procedural law of industrial property at the material time was contained in CARDINAL successive Codes of Industrial Property , the first introduced by LAW no . DATE of CARDINAL DATE and the second by LAW no . CARDINAL of DATE . It was the latter Code which the domestic courts applied in the instant case .

CARDINAL . The DATE Code provided a right of priority identical to that set out in LAW ( Article CARDINAL ) . Priority was determined by reference to the date the application for registration was filed ( Article CARDINAL ) . By virtue of Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL , the application for registration itself could be the subject of an assignment , with or without consideration , or a licence .
CARDINAL . The other provisions of the Code of relevance to the present case read as follows .

“ CARDINAL . The certificate of registration shall be issued to the interested party DATE after the time - limit for appealing has expired or , if an appeal has been lodged , once the final judicial decision has been delivered .
CARDINAL . The certificate shall be issued to the holder or to his or her representative upon presentation of a receipt . ”
“ An appeal against a decision of ORG may be lodged by the applicant , a person who has filed an opposition or any other person who might be directly affected by the decision . ”
“ Appeals must be lodged within DATE after the date of publication of the decision in ORG or , if earlier , the date a certified conformed copy of the decision is obtained . ”
“ CARDINAL . Registration shall also be refused of a mark ... containing CARDINAL or all of the following :
( j ) expressions or forms that are contrary to morals , domestic or Community legislation , or public order ;
( l ) signs liable to mislead the public , in particular as to the nature , quality , use or geographical source of the product or service to which the mark relates ;

CARDINAL . Appeals against a decision by the PERSON to register a mark had to be lodged with ORG ( Article CARDINAL of Legislative - Decree no . CARDINAL ) . The Code did not indicate whether they had suspensive effect .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( PERSON [ Case - law collection ] , DATE , vol . III , p. CARDINAL ) , ORG held that the mere filing of an application for registration conferred on the applicant a “ legal expectation ” ( expectativa jurídica ) that justified the protection of the law . LAW , which was introduced by LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE and came into force on DATE , provides “ provisional protection ” of the mark even prior to registration and entitles the applicant to bring an action in damages on the basis thereof .
